comment.author: 51979177@N02
comment._content: I wonder whether the caption might refer to Richard Sim, a miller, who appears to have had several bouts of insolvency...in 1875 nla.gov.au/nla.news-article13357166 ; in 1878 nla.gov.au/nla.news-article70594973 ...I suspect he was Richard Sim of 'Milthorpe', Hunter's Hill (? "Lane Cove") , whose daughter was married at All Saints, Hunters Hill, in December 1872 nla.gov.au/nla.news-article28412313 ... just going on this October 1877 SMH notice, by this time Sim appears to have moved from Hunters Hill to Glebe...where he looks to have had a fairly substantial residence (mid way down column 6) nla.gov.au/nla.news-article28396429 ; this May 1874 SMH marriage notice suggests Sim was then still at Milthorpe nla.gov.au/nla.news-article13341408 ; this January 1875 SMH births notice (for Brooke) suggests that Sim had moved out of 'Milthorpe' by this point nla.gov.au/nla.news-article13349811 ; Sim appears to have moved to Carcoar in the early 1880s...where he established a flour mill...his ?first wife Sarah died at Carcoar in 1885 nla.gov.au/nla.news-article13602464 ...he subsequently remarried (unhappily evidently going on various digitised newspaper hits nla.gov.au/nla.news-article13716581 )... In summary, I'd say this pic probably involves Sim's house 'Milthorpe', at Hunters Hill ("Lane Cove")...and that it would have been taken before Sim moved out in ca. 1873-1874... Now...if you google 'Milthorpe, Hunters Hill'...you discover that Milthorpe is heritage listed...was built in ca. 1872...and is located in Crescent St, Hunters Hill...so all up I'd say we're looking at ?1872-1874, and that we see Richard Sim, his wife Sarah, ?three of their children...and evidently their cat as well (sure it's not a large Siberian Hamster?)... I haven't yet been able to establish when Sim moved to Milthorpe...It would be good if someone could establish when Milthorpe was built...who the first owner was, etc...this might narrow the date range further...

comment.author: 51979177@N02
comment._content: 10 minutes later (!) - I'm not quite so sure about all the above now...on further investigation I see that Sim also lived at 'Clarence Villa', Hunter's Hill in the period ca. 1870-1872...he appears to have briefly owned both Clarence Villa and Milthorpe...and by December 1872 had both properties up for auction...(see notices top of column 2) nla.gov.au/nla.news-article13312439 ; per the description...'it has verandahs and balconies on three sides'...I still tend to think we're looking at Milthorpe...maybe (!). A google search indicates that Clarence Villa was built in 1858 by Jules Joubert...and that it was located in McBride Avenue, Hunters Hill...it was later re-named 'Rocklea', then 'Asseroe' ... and later still 'the Haven'... author, feminist, etc Maybanke Anderson evidently lived there in her later years... adb.anu.edu.au/biography/anderson-maybanke-susannah-5018 ; poem 'The Battery Has Gone' nla.gov.au/nla.news-article16282681 ; poem 'A Song of Old Sydney' nla.gov.au/nla.news-article16264130 ; 'A Tribute' nla.gov.au/nla.news-article16381818 ; her item on Rose Scott etc - nla.gov.au/nla.news-article16232468 ;

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/51979177@N02] Great stuff! There's another view of the Simms family (!) domestic bliss in the 'burbs from this wonderful album - investigator.records.nsw.gov.au/asp/photosearch/photo.asp...

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content: I would say that it is definitely the McBride Avenue, Hunters Hill address, Clarence Villa. See the hipped roof, 3-sided verandah, and chimneys on this GoogleSatelliteImage - maps.google.com.au/maps?q=McBride+Avenue,+Hunters+Hill,+N...

comment.author: 51979177@N02
comment._content: Where's GoogleDrone when you need it! Just going on GoogleSat I'd say we're looking at Clarence Villa. Beachcomber the 2nd pic is great too! Looks as though it was taken on the same occasion. Now we need to establish the period in which Sim was at Clarence Villa. This August 1868 SMH notice has Clarence Villa up for sale (column 5, 3rd from top) nla.gov.au/nla.news-article13171209 ...This item indicates Sim purchased Clarence Villa in ?late August 1868 nla.gov.au/nla.news-article13172206 ...so if this is Clarence Villa (and I don't think there can be much doubt that it is...the roof we see on the GoogleSat view matches exactly)...then provided we are in fact looking at the Sim family, I'd say the SRNSW pic(s) would have been taken in the period 1868-1872... This other SMH Auction notice has a better description of Clarence Villa (bottom of column 3) - nla.gov.au/nla.news-article13259541 ...note the room which had been adapted as a school room! A good deal of bio info on Richard Sim and his family can be scraped together from various sources...Sim was evidently born in the Truro district of Cornwall in 1829. He died at Rylstone in 1914...his first wife Sarah was born in 1831 at Bristol...she was a daughter of Rev. George Whiteford (d. 1876), of Liverpool NSW...Richard Sim and Sarah Whiteford were married in 1852....they appear to have had ?9 or so children...Alfred (b. 1868) and Elizabeth (b. 1874) died as infants...the others were...Emma (b. 1853), Mary/Marian (b. 1855), Joseph (b. 1858), Sarah (b. 1863), Louisa (b. 1866), William (b. 1868), Mabel (b. 1870)... no wonder they had a large house! I wouldn't like to speculate on which of the children we see in this pic!

comment.author: 51979177@N02
comment._content: acms.sl.nsw.gov.au/album/albumView.aspx?acmsID=403632&amp... also check this image of 'The Haven' in the Douglass Baglin Collection at the SLNSW (image 20)...looks like the verandah has been enclosed/rebuilt at some point.

comment.author: 51979177@N02
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/56925482@N07] Before Flickr and the digitised newspapers and the various digitised photo collections, etc, I used to spend my idle hours playing chess...not that I had much to show for it...at last count my computer had stretched its lead to at least 3,000 games. Trying to discover information about old photos is much more fun...it's a bit like going for a ride in a time machine!

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/51979177@N02] Here's a challenge for you - see if you can find out a connection between The Sims (!) and John Degotardi Snr who is likely to be the photographer, other than just commercially for these couple of photos. I am wondering why they feature in this album ... See research developing on the Archives Outside Blog , and on the following photo - [http://www.flickr.com/photos/state-records-nsw/8595447555/]
